## The Little Prince Reaches 600 Translations in 2024

The Little Prince, Saint Exupéry's masterpiece, has become the most translated fiction book in the world with now 600 translations! This historic milestone was achieved in 2024 with the translation into Dulegaya, the language of the Guna people of Panama.

### The 600th Translation Details

1,500 copies of this Dulegaya edition, entitled Sagla Massi Bibbi, were printed in the spring of 2024 by the Panamanian publishing house El Hombre de la Mancha.(no content)They will be distributed in schools and libraries in the Guna Yala region as of 2025.(no content)This version, rendered in Dulegaya, the language of the Guna people of Panama, is part of the "The Little Prince at the Service of World Languages" program. The initiative, launched and led by PIAF, aims to support endangered languages through the translation and publication of this literary masterpiece.

### Status as Most Translated Non-Religious Book

"The Little Prince" holds the title of the most translated non-religious book, appearing in 500+ languages. However, this information appears to be outdated, as more recent sources confirm the book has now reached 600 translations.

The 600th translation confirms the cultural and social impact of the Little Prince, which transcends borders and becomes a link between peoples.

### Historical Context and Evolution

The Wikipedia entry notes that The book has been translated into over 505 different languages and dialects worldwide, being the second most translated work ever published, trailing only the Bible. However, this information appears to be from an older version, as the official sources confirm the 600 translation milestone in 2024.

Earlier counts include:
- 80 years after its first publication, Saint-Exupéry's The Little Prince has now been translated and published in almost 540 languages, making it the most translated work of fiction in the world. (as of 2023)
- The Little Prince has captured the hearts of readers around the world, being translated into over 571 languages and dialects (as of February 2024)

### Cultural Significance

"With this 600th translation, The Little Prince reaffirms its status as a universal work, reaching an ever-wider and more diverse audience. Beyond borders and cultures, this tale symbolizes the beauty of meeting and dialogue between men." Olivier d'Agay, president of the Antoine de Saint Exupéry Youth Foundation.(no content)Today, with many languages on the brink of extinction, The Little Prince uniquely preserves languages and transmits cultures. Thanks to the passion of translators, this work has been translated into rare languages and endangered dialects, thus contributing to the preservation of the world's linguistic heritage.
